conclusion: Four objects on a green surface casting shadows labeled A, B, C, and D.
Objects include a glove/hand, a floral-patterned water bottle, an unknown object, and a roll of tape.
Understanding shadow formation: shadow forms opposite the light source; depends on distance and angle.
Current light source position is above and to the right, creating shadows extending left and downward.
Shadow origin points remain fixed at the base of each object when light source moves downward.
Shadows will extend more horizontally from the objects when light source moves downward.
Shadows will become larger/longer when light source moves downward.
Shadows will become less sharp and more diffuse if light source becomes larger in angular size.
Penumbra of each shadow may increase when light source moves downward.
Shadow A will extend further to the left and elongate.
Shadow B will extend further horizontally and become longer and potentially wider.
Shadow C will extend further horizontally and elongate.
Shadow D will extend further horizontally and become longer; shadow shape may change dramatically.
Final answer: Shadows will extend more horizontally, become larger and longer, less sharp, and angle will decrease.
